sentence: The market was able to come out of the gates strong today on the heels of recent retail sales that came in better-than-expected.
The rally failed to hold up as sellers moved in late in the day.
Home Depot ( HD ) and Estee Lauder ( EL ) rallied on their earnings reports, while shares of Dick's Sporting Goods ( DKS ) are lower despite a seemingly good quarter out of the company.
Despite Home Depot's profit beat, revenues were up less than 2% from last year's levels.
This is the pattern we have been seeing over and over this quarter, yet the market is ignoring this part of the fundamental reality (sluggish revenue growth, if any growth at all).
Elsewhere, shares of Coach ( COH ) ended lower as competitor Michael Kors ( KORS ) came in with numbers that easily trumped analyst expectations.
Finally, shares of credit card plays MasterCard ( MA ) and Visa ( V ) were higher, benefiting from this morning's retail sales data.

The Truth is out There Somewhere

In keeping with yesterday's theme of the wealthy continuing to build cash reserves and having ample liquidity, one can't help but think that frustration levels are only going to grow.
Looking around the markets, it is easy to understand why consistent, successful investors remain perplexed as to what direction they should be heading.

The momentum crowd is seeing a tale of two cities where growth companies like Coach ( COH ) and Nike ( NKE ) are saying things look dicey in the months/years ahead, while Under Armour ( UA ) and Michael Kors ( KORS ), which are much smaller companies in similar markets, are doing just fine.
These sort of discrepancies are part of the growing problem analysts and market watchers have picked up on, where economic and company data show little correlation to pricing performance.
Furthermore, seemingly every major economic metric has been wildly inconsistent, with no clear trend emerging whatsoever.
Every other data point runs counter to the month prior.
This patterns has repeated itself for the past few years straight.
Just this morning, for example, we had retail sales beating consensus estimates on one hand, but small business optimism hitting 9-month lows on the other.
You'd be hard pressed to find an analyst out there who could make sense of such conflicting data.
When I talk to real estate investors, some continue to wait for deals on income-producing properties at valuations that make sense in this current environment.

With banks and lenders remaining lax on enforcing borrowers to remain timely on payment obligations, the process of smart real estate investors capitalizing on those who overextended themselves during the recent bubble remains elusive.
Investors who aren't able to exercise patient are now resorting to buying foreclosures to generate rental income.
As I've mentioned previously, the quality of rental tenants in these sort of properties will probably be very low.
The fact that so many rely on government assistance in this country is also making for quite an elusive "bottom" for the economy.
With little to fear from institutions enforcing loan obligations, the sense of urgency for a many borrowers is simply not there.

We keep getting deluged with housing data and calls for prices bottoming, not to mention the constant push for one to own their own home, but with the health of the job market remaining stagnant in many areas, the idea of having the right financial strategy in place is thrown out the window.
One thing you must never forget when it comes to real estate is that every market is unique, and the money spent in one area will not net the same returns elsewhere.
Real estate is a highly localized market and will always remain so.
The truth is there are few areas where price appreciation can be factored into one's investment at this point.
This isn't a rant to bash real estate as an investment option.
I just want to remind investors out there to pay close attention to the zip code of any property you're considering.
Always carefully analyze the realistic potential upside value, given current market conditions and the immediate area.
The same idea goes for buying businesses.
In reality, there simply aren't many truly great turn-key small business operations out there.
You can go on BizBuySell.com (or other similar sites that feature businesses for sale), and you'll see no shortage of owners looking to move on to another chapter in their lives.
In some cases, you may be able to find a motivated seller of a thriving business, but you have to do your homework.
Hence, the frustration carries over to the equity markets as well, along with the recent big drop in trading volume.

With many questioning the effects of high-speed trading, trading scandals, and earnings results with little correlation within the same sectors, it is not hard to fathom how business media ratings continue to plunge to all-time lows.
The focus is on finding so-called investors the "trade of the day" and not the best stock candidates to help one grow wealth over time.
Most analysts continue to see nearly all stocks as buys for the most part, even though the risk-reward metrics don't add up.
Look no further than this morning as analysts are still scrambling to remove Groupon ( GRPN ) from their firm's "Buy" ratings list.
This recent "dot-bomb" dud has now fallen more than 78% (to under $6) from its $26 IPO price in Nov. 2011.
Is it any wonder why I constantly warn investors about chasing the flavor-of-the-day fad stocks?
We'll continue to track all the factors mentioned above, and how all this info can play into one's ability to build wealth over time.
One thing you can count on moving forward is that many analyst will continue to talk their book (applaud the stocks they own), whether the advice is good for the investor or not.
Eventually the market weeds out the awful truth, and investors learn some painful lessons.
Unfortunately, the next piece of bad advice is always just around the corner.
It's up to you and only you to figure out who you can trust in these markets.
I'll be here to help!
At Dividend.com, we maintain our focus on the best income-producing investments the markets have to offer during time of heightened volatility.
We want to make sure we have only the most pullback-resistant names on our Best Dividend Stocks List .
Also, if we see the market putting in what looks like a decent bottom, we will be prepared to scale up the list of stocks we like.
Stay tuned and be sure to look for Dividend.com Premium member alerts along the way.
Don't count on the government or your employer to set you up for a remarkable retirement.
Take control, do your own research, and achieve your goals yourself!
